NewWords.WordPhrase: (使)成为现实
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Her dream of being a college student has turned into a reality.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a car 汽车
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. An automobile usually has four wheels and an internal-combustion engine, used for land transport.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. producing much money; profitable 生利的，赚钱的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Many ex-army officers have found lucrative jobs in private security firms.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. (esp US) now; in a short time, soon 现在，目前；不久
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We presently have no plans to expand our business overseas, but that may well change in the future.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (AmE) 万亿，1012；(BrE) 百万兆，1018
n. 制造业  a. 制造业的，制造的  manufacture vt. make (goods) on a large scale using machinery （大量）制造
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Britain now manufactures approximately 40 per cent of Europe's desktop computers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make (sth.) change completely or in a dramatic way 彻底改革，使发生革命性剧变
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Computers have revolutionized banking.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  传感器；探测设备
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A sensor is a device that converts measurable elements of a physical process into data meaningful to the computer.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad.  more or less exactly; about近似；大概  approximate a.  fairly correct or accurate but not completely so 近似的；大概的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Approximately $150 million is to be spent on improvements on school buildings.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (fml) a death caused by accident or in war, etc. （事故或战争等造成的）死亡
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Britain has thousands of road fatalities every year.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. remove (sb./sth.) that is not wanted or needed; get rid of 消除；消灭；排除
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Chinese government approved a new plan to eliminate illiteracy nationwide by 2006.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 酒精，乙醇
n.  汽；雾；蒸汽
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The atmosphere always contains some moisture in the form of water vapor.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 空气中；在空中；悬而未决
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There is a peculiar smell in the air.

NewWords.WordPhrase: begin or begin working, running, etc. 发动，启动；开始
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Peter looked in his mirror and started up the engine.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. warn (sb.) that there may be danger, trouble, etc. 使警觉，使警惕；使注意
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The manager alerted the staff to the crisis facing the company.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 雷达，无线电探测器
n. （汽车）保险杠；减震器；缓冲器
n.  车道
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The newly-built highways have two lanes for each direction of travel.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the first model or design of sth. from which other forms are copied or developed 原型；样品
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Bell uttered to his assistant the words, "Mr. Watson, come here; I want you," using a prototype telephone.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. dull and never changing or varying; constant and boring 单调的；一成不变的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Robots are used in repetitive, monotonous tasks in which human performance might degrade over time.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  of or producing hypnosis or a similar condition 催眠的；有催眠作用的
n.  分开物；分隔物；分配器
ad. extremely 十足；严重地   gross a. glaringly obvious; whole; total 显而易见的；总的；毛的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Funding of education has been grossly inadequate for years.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a thing that can be dangerous or cause damage; a danger or risk 危害；危险
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The research has confirmed that tobacco smoke presents a hazard to health.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. （汽车等的）仪表板
n. 眼睑，眼皮
a. (usu derog) not regular or even in movement, quality or behavior; not reliable 不规则的，无常的；不可靠的
be unable to move or to be moved 停留，被阻塞
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I was stuck in the traffic yesterday for about one hour. That's why I missed the plane.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  卫星
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Engineers have developed many kinds of satellites, each designed to serve a specific purpose or mission.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. (cause to) move rapidly and continuously backwards and forwards; shake（使）振动，颤动，摇摆
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Microwave ovens operate by agitating the water molecules in the food, causing them to vibrate, which produces heat.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 频率；次数；重复发生率
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Fatal road accidents have decreased in frequency over recent years.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 量子
transmit (a signal, etc.) by radio waves, etc.; send from a central point 用（无线电波等）发送（信号等）；发送
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The yacht sent out a distress signal which was picked up by a passing steamer.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. (cause to) change from one form or use to another （使）转变，（使）改变
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Solar cooking requires a dark pot to absorb the sun's rays and convert them into heat energy.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 导航的，领航的
n. the ability or power to do sth. 能力
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. These tests are beyond the capability of an average 12-year-old.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  bring (sth.) into a mutual relationship (with another)使(与…)相互关联
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A mother's smoking in pregnancy correlates with low birth weight in her baby.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 旋转，转动   rotate v. move or make (sth.) move in circles around a central point（使）旋转，（使）转动
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Earth completes 366 rotations about its axis in every leap year.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 微芯片，微晶片
ad.  极端地；激烈地，猛力地   drastic  a.  having a strong or violent effect 极端的；激烈的，猛力的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Services have been drastically reduced.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the action or an instance of putting a theory, discovery, etc. to practical use 应用；运用
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Multimedia applications usually require more computer memory and processing power.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. 使做好准备   be poised to (do) be ready to take action at any moment 做好准备随时（做…）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The automobile company is poised to launch its new advertising campaign.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 徒步旅行者
n.  the branch of information technology which deals with the long-distance transmission of computerized information 远程信息学
n. 公路；交通干线
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Traffic along major highways in some cities is monitored by remote cameras, radar, or sensors in the roadway.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. fix (sth.) in position for use, display or study; put (sth.) into place on a support 将…固定住；将…置于架上
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some automobiles were designed with a transmission mounted on the rear axle.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. device or equipment for transmitting radio or other electronic signals 发射机；发报机
n. a thing that is in the way of sb./sth. 障碍物   obstruct v. be or get in the way of (sb./sth.); block 阻碍；阻塞
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. John was irritated by drivers parking near his house and causing an obstruction.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. between states, esp. in the USA （美国）州与州之间的，州际的
v. (usu passive) use machines to do work previously done by people 使自动化
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. This part of the assembly process is now fully automated.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 磁的；有磁性的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Rubber is not magnetic.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  大钉；道钉
控制
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The new manager didn't know how to take control of his company.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v.  travel over 在…上通行
v. group together 使成一束（或一捆等）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They bunched together to allow others to squeeze into the crowded elevator.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. supporter of sth. 促进者；助长者
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. an enthusiastic promoter of good causes

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. equip with computers 使计算机化
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The accounts section has been completely computerized.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make (sth.) part of a whole 将…包括进去
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His newly published book incorporates his earlier essays.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a thing that is good or helpful for sb; a benefit; an advantage 特别有用的东西；好处；利益
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A bicycle is a real boon when you live in a small town.

NewWords.WordPhrase: too 也，又
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She wanted to produce the play and to direct it as well.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. become or make sth. smaller or fewer 减少
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A single solar cooker can save a ton of firewood per year and decreases carbon dioxide emissions.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 污染
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. One of the greatest challenges caused by air pollution is global warming.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 扩大；扩展；发展
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Modern cosmologists are continuously calculating the age, density, and rate of expansion of the universe.
